div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT STEAMERS and RAILWAYS
div.p: xpress service from November 1st, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. From Nov 1st sleeping and dining acrs on Egyptian State Railways are attactched to ordinary trains from Cairo on Mon, Wed and Sat, at 8 p.m. and from Luxor on Tues., Thurs, and Sun, at 5.30 p.m- From 2nd Dec. Luxe trains with sleeping and dining Cars will run on same days leaving Cairo and Luxor at 6.30 p.m.. Early in January these trains will be run daily. Express between Shellal and Halfa carry mails and 1st class passengers only, but 2nd class passengers may be accepted if accomodation is available. Express steamers do not stop at any stations on either up or down journeys between Shellal and Halfa. To insure accommodation official passengers must have warrants stamped "Accommodation Available" by Sudan agent, Cairo, or Civil Secretary, Khartoum. A specially fitted barge with 1st and 2nd class accomodation for native ladies will be attactched to these steamers. There will be a resurateur on these mail steamers.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Isolation of American Banks
div.p: The peculiarities of the banking system in the United states are producing some curious results in the present financial crisis. The country, as is well known, has no institutions corresponding to our great joint-stock banks— no companies with a head office in the metropolis and branches in important centres. Every National bank is confined to a single building, and every State bank to a single city, so that American banking is carried on in water-tight compartments ; and in a period of strained credit each town is dependent on its own resources, fending for itself, and protecting its own store of money from the demands of outside bankers. Out of this peculiarity has developed during the present crisis what is described as "a blockade of domestic exchange," a picturesque phrase signifying that it is difficult, or impossible, to transmit money from one city to another. The country banks have been withdrawing their deposits from New York, so that a cheque from a distance cannot be collected in New York without great delay, and is consequently of very little value im the payment of debts. Some remarkable examples of this difficalty have been quoted recently by the "Financial News" correspondent, who tells us that cheques on Chicago cannot be collected for New York merchants in leas than a month, and that cheques on Philadelphia, which is only 90 miles distant, cannot be collected at all. The financial connection between city and city has been suddenly snapped, and the result is a dislocation of trade the importance of which can scarcely he exaggerated. We are told that provincial manufacturers, whose cheques have become valueless, cannot pay their workmen ; that New Yorkers cannot get payment for debts of long standing, and that thousands of men are being thrown out of employment. A telegram in Tharsday's "Times" states that —

In Chicago 90 per cent. of the factories and shops have curtailed their staffs and the hours of working. Forty per cent. of the building workers and 25 per cent. of the wood workers are idle. From Pittsburg it is reported that manufactories within a radius of 50 miles have dismissed 48,000 men, and that 2,000 railwaymen have been discharged. Large manufactories in Indianopolis have dispensed with half their hands During the past two days 21 sawmills in Northern Wisconsin have closed, throwing out 6000 men. At Wilmington 4,000 men have been discharged trom mills, and one firm has reduced its pay-roll from $28,000 (£4.60) to $7,000 (£1,400).

Comment on these figures is unnecessary, but they confirm us in our belief that a central bank is urgently needed in the United States. After their bitter experieace of trusts, Americans are, not unnaturally, reluctant to allow any more industries to be centralised, and there is no doubt a danger that an institution on the lines of the Bank of England might be captured by private interests. But the present system of "'each city for itself and devil take the hindmost" does not work smoothly in time of panic. If distances are too great to allow one bank to act for the whole of the 'States, it might be possible to divide the country. into sections with a central institation in each. ("The Economist").

div.head: Egyptian Land Investments
div.p: At an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of this company, which was held at Alexandria last week, it was decided to distribute the unengaged assets of the company among the shareholders up to 25 per cent of the capital without prejudice to the annual dividend, which will be distributed io January.

div.head: P.W.D. Report
div.p: It has been announced by a contemporary that the Public Works Department has issued its annual report, and a complaint has been made thatit should not have been forwarded to the press. The report in question has not yet been published this year and we are further in formed that copies will be sent to the press, as in former years, immediately upon publication.

div.head: Cairo Motor Omnibuses
div.p: The Cairo Tramway Company have now six motor omnibuses on the streets, the route covered being from the station to Abdiri, a journey which is accomplished in six minutes. The Company has altogether 15 cars, supplied by English and Freuch firms, both of which are, we understand, giving every satisfaction. The remaining nine cars will not be out for passenger traffic until after the opening of the new depot, when a service will be started to and from the Mousky.

div.head: The "Egyptian Standard"
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel announces that the new issue of capital for his newspaper is being readily subscribed and that many Europeans are coming forward with subscriptions. Meanwhile the troubles between the Pasha and his European Editors are increasing. Mr Charles Rady, the Editor of the "Egyptian Standard," is shortly leaving and now it is announced that Mr. H. Kastner, the Editor-in Chief of Kamel's French organ, "L'Etendard Egyptien," is also going A French Cairo contemporary, * propos of Mr. Kastner's approaching departure, remarks : Serait-ce par raison d'économie ' Nons ne voyons pas «d'autre motif, notre confrére ayant toujours rempli son devoir avec une loy auté et une conscience fort remarquables, H Kastner ade plus du talent. c'est peut-étre ce qtli géne son entourage—dn tact et de l'autorité, Aprés Saint Ogan, Rudy,aprés Rudy, Kastner. A qui le tour

div.head: Savoy Palace Hotel.
div.p: The Savoy Palace, the rendezvous du chic monde d'Alexandrie, is receiving daily its full quota of visitors, and, under the popular and able management of Mr. G. Brey, is earning for itself a popularity equivalent to its exceptional deserts. The hotel, though not "full to over flowing," has but few empty rooms from day to day, and many of the members of Alexandria Society meet there for afternoon tea, dinner or supper. The Borghesi orchestra, which plays from 5 to 7p.m., fully sustains its reputation and attracts many parties for the "five o'clock." Yesterday afternoon the magnificent winter garden of the hotel presented very animated appearance, being crowded by those who had come to listen to the orchestra. Prominent among the hosts of the afternoon was Mr. Leon Constantinidis, who was enter taining a party of 38, and we also several other smaller parties.

div.head: New Khedival Hotel

The band will also play before and dyting dinner, while thé following special dinner at P.T. 30 will be served: Petite Marmite Henry IV, Supréme de sole & la Joinville, pommes en serviette, Filet de boeuf Prince Albert, ov Poularde de Bresse a l'archiduc, Langouste A la Parisienne, Faisans de Bohéme truffés, salade Demidoff Asperges d'argenteuil, sance hollandaise, Bombe Monte Christo, Gateau marquis, Fruits The orchestra, which is composed of select Vienna artists and which played on different occasions before the Emperor of Austria and a great many other notabilities, should be a great shocess. Tables tor dinner can be booked at the hotel office.

div.head: London Opinion
div.p: It is of great inaportance to the Nationalists in Egypt, of whatever party they may belong to, to know how recent events in this country are viewed by the Radical sections of the Liberal Party, who have of late shown such a lively interest in Egyptian politics The following communication from a London Radical, who is following the march of events here with keen interest, deserves reproduction and may cause the followers of Mustapha Pasha Kamel to reflect on the wisdom of pursuing a line of policy which will inevitably estrange all English sympathy, even of the most advanced kind, from their aims. From our point of view we cannot regard this estrangement between Kamel and that mischievoas section of the Liberal Party with any bat a feeling of sincere satistaction and Mustapha Pasha Kamel has most effectually served the interests of Imperialistic policy in regard to Egypt by alienating Mr. Robertson, M-P., and all his clique The communication ia as follows :—

This is the time of year when the lucky ones leave our inclement climate and make tracks for Egypt, where meteorological conditions are kinder, and where, if we are to believe reports and the pictorial advertisements of the steamship companies, the sun shines all day long in the most gratifying way. The means of reaching Cairo are nowadays simple. Egypt looks very attractive in the pictures, a land seemingly of beauty and poetry, fair ladies, and blue seas, yellow sands, romantic architecture, end alot of other truly delightful accessories. A land without trouble, of course. So the onlooker might think, but he would not be quite absolutely correct. I have been favoured with a copy of "L'Etendard Egyptien', coutaining a complete report of a lengthy speech by Mustapha Pasha Kamel, a verbose gentleman whose "facgon d'agir" seems to stand before the international fire and throw on fat. It does not seem to me to be a particularly wise proceeding. Somebody seems to bave bid him discourse, and he has done so with a vengeance.

"It is much more in your way than mine" was the remark ofthe man in Pickwick who had got over the wall to his friend, who was still in the lane, down which a mad bull was gaily stampeding Rhetoric is very much in Musta pba Pasha Kamel's way, but surely he might have a little credit here and there to the English. It seems a thousand pities to find that England is so much in the wrong. People were realising that a better understanding had come about and that thanks to the visit to this country of the Sheikh Ali Bey Youssef and Hafiz Effendi Awad, there has been a real and genuine increase of the even previously existing entente cordiale between England and Egypt. I come now to another point. It is to my mind a matter of grave disrespect to his Highness the Khedive, who has friends in the Courts of Europe, and who is persona grata'at Windsor and Buckingham Palace, to voice sentiments such as one finds in the feverish harangue which I have before me. No; this speaker is no friend of Egypt, no. loyal son of a great country, no sincere worker, to utter what are really ineptitudes, and to indulge in "angry criticism, and subversive speculation which if taken seriously might do irreparable harm. The unthinking applause of an excited multitude, the fever of a night, the dangerous emotions superinduced by a flow of words,are,maybe momentarily fascinating things, but afterwards Aprés, messieurs, c'est l'abime. Is it possible that a man should be so avid of the fleeting distinction of a mob orator as to risk all, or does he forget the real meaning of his words, their true significance? If he forgets, others do not, others who are for prudent action and wise counsels. What does the man want? War? Is it so? If for the sake of argument, that is the idea at the back of his rhetorical brain, let him realise that the tub thampers have a very short public career when trouble does come. Nobody listens to them then. Oris he a farceur, a mere manipulater of words, scornfully careless of what may be their effect ? In any case, may be some wise friend will advise him as to the grievous mistakes of his poliey —a policy so unfortunate as to make wen stare aghast. Fortunately we live in' sounder, more philosophic times. But there have been hours, periods of "Starm and Drang" in the history of nations when speeches such as this: would have occasioned dire peril and rendered the "posear" a real enemy to his race. No, this man who affects stern virtues does not, canvot calmly realise the sharpness of the tools with which he plays. Can he not be serionsly warnéd that he is really doing Egypt a grave disservice ' He talks much of his cause and of the Egyptians. He has borrowed a little of the cheaper French style of eloquence. But what precisely is his cause? If he is really serious he is a most dangerous man whose exuberance should be checked. Men who know the truth disregard his utterances. That is well. Yet there are others who are always susceptible to strident talking. One knows those others. They can be imposed upon ; they can be led away. In every nationality their representatives are to be found. Still there is this to be said. Maybe the speaker deceives himself. To disregard all that has been and that is, and to elaborate elementary theofies of patriotism. That is his plan 'Renaissance d'une nation," "ames généreuses"—one knows them all, all these pet phrases of one who speaks before he thinks, but does not trouble to think before he speaks. Then we have words, words. words ; and the day for such bas gone by. Englishmen are not fools ; they are not hypocrites, They deplore such appeals to elemental instincts. Mustapha Pasfia Kamel declaims about national aspirations, with a reckless disregard of consequenses He recalls to one the days when General Boulanger mistaking his role of a fair soldier,took to sporting, as he thought, for his country's good. And yet there is good in Mustapha Pasha Kamel, if he would forget self, be reasonable and listen to others on occasion. He jas force, enterprise, energyall excellent qualities with which he might serve his country and serve it well. But he could not be gentler in his treatment of England, releasing it from the frightfully dark cloud under which the British Empire has lain in gloom since that memorable discourse.

div.head: Cairo Water Commission
div.p: The members of the Cairo Water Commis sion are still busily occupied in their investigations, and it isnot expected that their re port will be sentin for nearly fortnight yet. In the meantime every point connected with the matter is being carefully gone into and examined, and we may expect a thoroughly exhaustive and lucid report when the time comes for its publication. It has been said that difficulties in the way of complete in- vestigation have been increased rather than diminished by the Sanitary Department. The fertility of imagination displayed by various people in the concoction of statementd such as these is really remarkable, for, as may be imagined, there is not a particle of truth in them, and on the contrary the Sanitary Department is displaying great activity in the collection of any details which would be likely to assist the commission in their work. The first work undertaken by the commission was the examination of previous reports on the subject of their investigation and holding as we do some confidence in the abilities of the members of this commission we hardly con- sider it probable that their decision will be based upon anything but actual experiments, valuable as the complete knowledge of former reports undoubtedly is.

If the water of the Rhodah Farag wells is unfit for drinking purposes, we imagine that the public need have no canse to fear that they will not be informed ot the fact, and that immediate steps will be taken to remedy the matter. If on the other hand the commission find that the water is pure and fit for consamption, we may be equally sure of the validity of their decision. The commission is formed of learned men who know their business and not of those likely to be blinded by the suppression of a report, as some of the inhabitants of Cairo would apparently have us believe. We can assure the public that any accusations of this kind which are made against the Sanitary Department are entirely without foundation. Any one having information which would be likely to be of use has only to apply to the Department in order to see hag baseless these rumours are. But though baseless they are undoubtedly injurious to the commanity at large inasmuch as they tend to destroy confidence in the commission itself.

div.head: Obituary
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mr, D. K. Reid, senior partner in the firm of Messrs. Reid and Barnard, the stock and sharebrokers of Alexandria, Cairo and London. Mr. Reid had been in a delicate state of health for many years past and has lately been staying at San Remo on the Riviera, where he expired. The news of his death will be received in Egypt with great regret for during his tesidence in this country he had gained the esteem of a large circle of friends and acquaintances.

The deceased was thirty seven years of age and was unmarried. He was the son of the late Mr. David Reid, a well-known member of the London Stock Exchange, of Caythorp Hall, near Grantham, Lincolnshire. He was educated at Winchester and Magdelen College, Oxford. Mr. D. K. Reid was a member of the board of directors of the Hamburg-Anglo- American Nile Company
We beg to tender our sympathies in their bereavement to his brother, Mr. J. L. Reid and to Messrs. Barnard, his, partners.

div.head: Maitre Carton De Wiart
div.p: We extract the following from the "African World"

An esteemed legal correspondent writes:— Among those called tothe Bar at Gray's Inn this week was Maitre Léon Constant Ghislain Carton de Wiart, the famous Cairo advocate, who paid us a flying visit this week, remaining in London only 48 hours. Me Carton de Wiart was descri as LL.D. of the Univer- sity of Brussels, advocate of the Belgian Bar, member of the Order of Advocates, Egypt, only son of Adrian Carton de Wiart, of Brassels, deceased. The ancient Inn is rapidly becoming one of the mogt popular of the foar Inns of Court, and numbers many very distinguished gentlemen among the members, his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales being one of the benchers. The benchers,as is well known, form the governing body of the va- rious Ions, and their number is added to as occasion arises by their appointing some distinguished ordinary member of the Jnn to be a bencher. We hope the time will not be very far distant when their number may be augmented by Maitre Carton de Wiart, whose general record in Egypt and loyal services to British interests on the Nile bank have been of exceptional importance.

div.head: Conscription in Egypt
div.p: A rumoar is current in official circles to the effect tbat the Government have under consideration a scheme, which, if carried through, will be of very great advantage to time-expired soldiers in the Egyptian Army. No official information is yet to hand but it would appear to be certain that a proposal by which time expired soldiers would benefit materially by the revenue which is annually accumulated through the imposition of a fine of L.E. 20 on all those who would avoid military service in the country, is receiving the serious attention of the authorities. It is proposed to devotea portion of this revenue to a fund from which a soldier would, on the completion of his service, draw a settled sum in order to enable him to start as a civilian with a moderate capital and so counterbalance the lack of commercial or trade knowledge which is so frequently fatal to the success of a man who has spent the best years of his life in the service of his country, for the number of men who, during their term of service, are enabled to follow a trade, is necessarily limited, and the greater numbers are, when discharged at the expiration of their service, totally unfitted for the business life of the civilian, with the nataral consequence that the Army is looked upon by the majority of those who, by reason of lack of means, are forced to serve in it, as an almost insurmountable deterrent to a successful civilian life. But though this is undoubtedly the case, the Egyptian who would have been ready to sacrifice anything he possessed in order to be free from the application of a much dreaded conscription, is,when once he has been forced to accept the inevitable, a much keener soldier than his former conduct would have led any one to suppose that he was capable of becoming. It is in the first place simply due to the inhereit distaste of the Orieatal for any departure from the well-worn grooves to which he has for generations been accustomed, and in the second, he is troubled with a not unnatural fear. Bat at the completion of his military service, his position in his village will be to all intents and purposes, simply but a beginner while his contemporaries Of earlier days who have been fortunate enough to escape conscription would probably be too far advanced in worldly prosperity to admit of the barest chance of his ever raising himself to the same scale. But if the projected scheme should prove feasible, and the time-expired soldier instead lof being thrust back into the world with no particular branch of training which could be lof any material use to him, receive a sum which would enable him to bridge over the lost years of civilian experience by establishing himself in any manner he may choose as being most suited to his abilities, it is more than probable that conscription would quickly loses many of the unfavourable attributes which, to the eyes of the possible soldier, surround it at 'present. Conscription in every country where it obtains is prone to carry hardships in its train, but much would be done to alleviate these hardships in this country if it were felt that the sums of money, which the more fortunate of those who are eligible candidates, yearly pour into the treasury in order to escape the ranks, could be broaght to bear to the ultimate good of those whom circumstances compel to accept service.

div.head: Lord Cromer Fund
div.p: Referring to the paragraoh in our issue of yesterday we are informed that the AngloEgyptian Bank have agreed to accept the subscriptions for the Lord Cormer farewell testimonial and that Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt have undertaken to keep the accounts. The Committee request that intending subscribers will kindly send their offerings to the bank. We are further informed that it was unanimously decided to limit the subscribers to members or frims of the British community at Alexandria.

div.head: Egyptian Markets, LTD.
div.p: Since the time when we wrote in terms commendatory of the prospects of Egyptian Markets, Limited, the price of the shares has kept up very steadily, notwithstanding the ad- Verge influences which were calculated to depress it, in common with other companies connected with the country. The time of year has now artived when we may confidently look for an important improvement in the outlook for the shareholders. The money which annually flows in such a copious stream into Egypt after the harvest operations are concludéd must find its way into circulation somewhere; and no better or more certain channel can be found for attracting it than the mrrkets to which so many of the native dealers resort. The new functions which the company has now assumed in connection with the sale cannot fail to enormously increase the profits of its operations; so that those who intend to secure an interest in the undertaking should not delay in taking advantage of the opportunity. "Daily Report."

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
div.p: The October retarns of the National Bank of Egypt, which we published last week, appear to reflect the present reputed plethora of gold in the vaults of our local banks. Comparing the returns of October with the corresponding month of the previot& year, we find that the mnonntof notes and cash held in the department in ' October last stands at LE. 2,424,000, as against LB 1,029,000 in October, 1906. The amount to the credit of the Ministry of Finance Stands at L.E. 1,222,000, against L.E. 394,000 for the previous October. This increase seems, wholly or in part, due to the agreement made between the Egyptian Government and the National Bank of Egypt for a prompt return to ciculation of the amount paid by the fellaheen for the land tax. This wise provision has evidently hélped the situation materially. We wish that every local bank in Egypt would follow the excellent' example of the National Bank and publish their monthly retorns, which would throw much light on the financial situation.

div.head: Mena House Hotel
div.p: The bracing desert air and the charms of Mena House Hotel never fail to attract visitors to Egypt The season has started well and there are many visitors there, amongst whom are Mrs. Philip McGregor, Col. and Mrs. Ludlow, Mrs. Hague Cook, Mr. Axel Th. Preyer (Consul des Pays-Bas) Mr. and Mra. Maurice Graham, Miss Edwards, Mrs. and Miss Lucena, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Philpott, Mr. Adel Hay Hilmi, Mrs. Joseph Bey Chédid, Mrs. Marianne Frank, Mrs. Ponsonby Willner, Mr. Rassell Rea, M. P. and Mrs. Russell Rea, Dr. Felkin, Mrs. Wynne Houlkes, Mr. Vau igham Williams, Mrs and Miss Hosey, Dr. Fenton, Mr. and Mrs Trevithick, Miss Alison Garland, Miss Norton, Miss Morell and many others. An excellent band plays every Tuesday and Saturday, during luncheon and afternoon-tea. On such occasions, many Caird residents are to be seen on the terrace. To night the first ball will be given in the beavtiful mosque hall. No invitations will be issued to the usual patrons of the hotel, but all will be cordially welcomed to the first dance of the season. The King's Royal Rifles are camping in the neighbourhood of Mena House and their officers are frequently to be seen in the dining hall. They are expected to attend the ball and give that tonch of brightness to the gay scene to which the military uniform lend's itself so admirably.

div.head: The National University
div.p: It is understood that the new "Party of the People," will take into its own province the propaganda of the scheme for an Egyptian University. Its fortunes, though brilliant at the start, have languished of late, and as the fund subscribed has been standing stationary at its total of 30,000 for several months past, it seemed only too probable that the svheme would collapse, as many Oriental ambitions have before it. Naturally it would confer great prestige on the new party if it succeeded in reviving and bringing to a successful conclusion the plan of founding a purely Egyptian seat of learning on the banks of the Nile-a university that should attract the whole of the Moslem world into its protals.

div.head: Delegation Municipale
div.p: Communication est donnee d'une note un chef du service des parcs et plantation, provoquee par l'Administateur, donnant le detail des depenses effectes par la Municpalite piur la transformation du jardin Nouzba. Ces despenses s'elevent a L.E. 3,800 environ et elles sont largement compensees par les rentrees que procure deji ce jardin, grace aux embellissements qui y ont ete apport's et qui ont permis a la Municipalite d'y louer in cafe-resturante, a raison de L.E. 340 pdr an, representant in rendemeut de dix pour cent environ. La seance est leve a 7 h. p.m. Une autre reunion aura lieu aujourd'hni mercredi 4 decembre 1907 pour l'examen du budget de 1908.

div.head: Supreme Consular Court
div.p: The first case down for hearing at the Alexandria Sessions of the Supreme Consular Court is that of Montana v. the Anglo Egyptian Bank Limited, which is to be heardon the 6th inst. The last case to be heard on is that of Rex. v. Cannon, Which is the 16th inst. This is the casé of a murdering another on board a ship in harbour The other cases are v. Rex. v. Clayton, two, application Baker and Barker deceased, and against the judgment of the by the Bourse and Banking Company Limited. The civil case of Dalgleish adjourned in Cairo, will be heard here Friday.

div.head: K.S.C. Racing.
div.p: Classification and measuring day is fixed for the 7th December at 3 p.m. at Ghezireh. Measurements and classification will hold good for big winter race meetings

div.head: Zagazig Races
div.p: The entries for these races have again proved exceedingly numerous, one race alone having 29 and another 18. The coarse has given a great deal of tronble owing to part having been recently flooded but ithas been brought into very fair order Visitors from Cairo can travel by the 11 a.m. to Zagnzig, where on arrival lench will be served iv a restaurant car in the station. Those wishing to engage tables should enter their names in the list at the Turf Club or inform the manager of the Wagon Lits company, For the joarney the 5 p.m to Benha will be the course to pick up passengers.

div.head: The Cairo Season
div.p: The Savoy Hotel, although only reopened a few days ago has a;ready 50 guests. Among the latest arrivals are the Duke and Duchess of Aosta, Capt. Piscicelli, Mr Alex G Moore and Miss J.C. Moore, Mrs. Hague Cook, the Hon,David FitzGerald, Mr and Mrs. Lang Anderson, Major Collins of the Scots Greys, Lady Evelyn COllins, daughter of the Dowager Duchess of Roxburgh, who are on their honeymoond, Mr. C.H. Ruddock and family from New York, and Mr. and Mrs. Fulkely Johnstone. The Duke and Duchess of Aosta are going to remain about a week in Cairo. The Duke will the return to Italy, while the Duchess is going to make a trip to Upper Egypt and the Sudan with a large party. They are going as far as the lake Victoria Nyanse. Major and Lady Evelyn COllins were married a few days ago in London.

The meeting of Congress has taken place. The proceedings were formal. Mr. Cortelyou's estimates for the year 1908-9 amount to 776,000,000 dollars, beings 77,500,000 above those for the 1907-8. The Congressman, Mr. Hayes of California, showed Mr. Roosevelt his bill for the restriction of Oriental immigrtantion. Mr. Roosevekt disapproved of it but Mr. Hayes will nevertheless push it on the ground that it accords with sentiments of the Californians. (Reuter)

Noisy antiGerman demonstration have taken place at Lemberg as a protest against the Prussian-Polish Legislation. The Emperor William was burned in effigy, Prince von Buelow denounced, and the German Consul threatened.

Reichsrath. The Premeir, referring to the Polish legislation, urged non interference with the affairs of an allied friendly state otherwise froegn relations would be exposed to continual disturbance and peace seriously threatened. (Reuter)
The money market is considerably easier. A large parcel of gold has arrivals are expected from India, Australia, and Singapore. There are general hopes of an early reduction in the bankrate. (Reuter)

The anti-Slavery Congress has been opened. It has many adhesions, including Signor Titoni and cardinal Merry Del Val. Commendatore Simonetti described the Sudan as the greatst slave market and urged England and France to prevent the merchandise of human flesh. (Reuter)

As a result of the money crisis in America an Armenian banking and commercial firm in Stambul has failed. Its liabilities amount to 200,000. The Ottoman Bank has come to the rescue in order to prevent a general collapse. (Reuter)
The Chamber of Deputies has ratified the treaty of Commerce with Russia. (Havas)
The first reserves composed of unmarried men between 18/30 have neen called out in Natal to patrol the country. (Reuter)
Mr. Taft has arrived. He will go tomorrow to Tzakor Selo.
Mr. Taft has arrived. He will be received by the Tsar at Tsarkoe Selo tommorrow(Reuter)

div.head: Oxyrhynchus Finds
div.p: Dr. Hunt and Dr. Grenfell, who found the "Sayings of Jesus" at Oxyrhynchus, in the Fayoum, have discovered other fragments on the same spot. These included, says Dr. Gren- fell, "a vellum fragment of an uncanonical gospel which would soon be published, relating to a conversation on the nature of purity between our Lord and a Pharisee, which is supposed to take place in the temple at Jeru- salem. It did not possess the antiquity or the importance of the 'Sayings of Jesus,' and was probably to be regarded as an elaboration of Matthew xv. 1-20, composed between a.d. 150 and a.d. 200: But the author was more successful than many writers of apocryphal gospels in catching something of the genuine ring, and the fragment wax a valuable addition to the scanty remnant of the numerous uncanonical traditions concerning Christ's teaching, which were current in many Christian comununities, especially in Egypt, during the third and fousth centuries.

At the last meeting of the Hellenic Society of London, held on the 14th inst., Dr. Grenfell gave a most interesting account, with quota tions, of Greek papyri recently found at Oxy rhynchas, including fragments of a new Greek historian, probably Theopompus, whom the explorers are inclined to rank in historical merit between Thucydides and Xenophon ; and considerable fragments of a lost play—the 'Hypsipele' of Euripides

Part V. of the 'Oxyrbynchus Papyri,' con taining several of the most important discover ies yet made by Drs. Grenfell and Hunt, will be issued shortly. The bulk of the volume is occupied by the new Preans of Pindar in honour of Abdera, Ceos, lpbi, and other cities, and the new historical work by a writer of the fourth century, supposed to be Theo pompus. Besides these there is an interesting fragment of an uncanonical Gospel, of which a separate edition will be issued simultaneously by Mr. Henry Frowde This relates to conver sation on the subject of purity between Christ and a chief priest, who is also a Pharisee, in the Temple at Jerusalem

div.head: Port Sudan
div.p: There appears to be a considerable amount of grumbling among the commercial portion of the population of Port Sedan' because things do not work as smoothly as it is claimed that they onght to. On the other hand it may be arged trom the officials' point of view that it is ridienlons to expect that in each a ready made town everything should proceed with the regularity that prevails in other centres of population, which have been settled for generations. Donbtless the trying climate is responsible for a great gleal of this discontent. In the following article we will endeavour to give an impartial view of the different standpoints.

The Civil Inspector of Port Sudan, Kaimakam Feilden Bey, is most corteous in giving all all information and he keeps his offices-open thrthroughout the day for callers and-all questions arepromptly answered.
The Complaints of the COmmercial class may be summarised as follows:-

In Port Sudan each department of the Government is independent of one another. All the shipping agencies are put at the back of the town instead of on the front, with the exception of the Khedivial Mail Company, who have the Government contract for the mails.

The most valuable commerecial sites have been monopolised By Government offieials and some of the officials have seleeted excellent sites on the front for their private residences, which would afford sites for commercial offices. We have been informed from official sourees that the only firm, which asked for a site on the front was the Khedivial Mail Company and it was given to them. The two most valuable sites on the front are open to be taken on lease.

To these official replies the rejoinder is made that the statement that only one firm asked for a site on the quay is not correct, and that in regard to the valuable sites: for lease on the front no business firm would look at them for the reasons given at length in our| article on the leases.

Representatives of British shipping interests say that it is absolutely necessary to have an Admiralty counseil on the spot to assist Sudan Government, if Port Sadan is to de velop in regard to shipping. At present there is pot a single English judge in the Sudan selected from the Admiralty Bar.

To this it is answered that in a country with such a small staff of officials, it is asking too mach to demand the appointment of specialist in legal matters. The present judge at Port Sadan and Suakim is a practical legal man and is considered to be one of the most competent members of the Bench in the Sudan.

Complaints are rife because ships have now to discharge at the temporary quays which are one and a half kilometre from the Customs warehouses, whither they have to be taken by lighter. Heavy goods cannot be taken down and have to be dumped on the quays by the crane. The result is that the ships that arrive from England every month with big cargoes are never less than a week in discharging. As an example of the delay we may cite the case of ten eases from the S.S. "Clydesdale," which arrived at the Customs on ~ November 18th, although that steamer left Port Sudan on the 31st October last

The reply of the Castomsauthorities to criticisms is that the commercial community has only to wait unti the new quays are built and then everything will go well. Business men ought to consider that Port Sudan is in the earliest stages of its development and allowances ought to be made for the great difficult ties, which are inherent in the satisfactory running of the Customs Administration in such an incohate port. As soon as the Customs staft is fully trained all their dithcalties will vanish. The official attitude is to throw the blame on the agents of the shipping companies. The tollowing paragraph, which has evidently been officially inspired, appeared recently in the "Sudan Times" :-

The complaints made about delays and short ages of goods at the Custom House Port Sudan, are attributable mostly to the incompetency of agents of Port Sudan. If the merchants took pains to choose as their representatives there persons who have experience in custom honse transactions, many of their complaints would be removed. It is not denied, however, that difficulty ot landing goods from steamers into lighters has much to do with the present disorder, but this will be removed as soon as the new quays are completed, when freight will be unloaded directly from steamers to cars.

The commercial class complain of the dilatorinees of the officials. One shipping agency asked tor a temporary site on the Customs side as its present offices are a kilometre on the other side of the harbour. No reply in writing was receivéd and now the agency has to have its weighing machines and other appliances lying unprotected on the spot near where the ships come in. 'The agent only wanted the site in order to warehouse the equipment necessary for an agency on the quay. The entire frontage on the Customs side is taken apand behind thisplots of land can be obtained on lease for warehouses but without access to the quay. The work of discharging lighters, ete access to the quay. This question has been veterred to Khartoum. It is considered that six hondred of metres of quays are enough, for the most exceptional ocurrence up to now has been the presence of four ships in the harbour at the same time. It is suggested that the Government should construct quays and let them to private firms, If this were done and the warehouses placed in front of the railway siding, the necessary access would be obtained.

Another source of discontent is the severe line of demonstation shown between the official and civilian elements of which the following is a sample. No English member of the non official community is allowed to import his new wine, while Government officials can freely do so. The reason is that no private person, whether he is a "bona fide" resident or not, is allowed to import wine fro private purpose and they are compelled to buy inferior stuff from the licensed dealer, who pay a heavy license, for that privilege. Recently, the English manager of a company imported some wine for his private consumption and was not permitted to use it when it arrived, He will consequently have to send it back to Europe or sell it to a licensed dealer and buy it back at a loss while he sees officials freely imperting their own wine. Such is one instance of the sources of discontent. It is trifling in itself, but little incidents like this case cause considerable annoyance and lead to a good deal of discontent.

The reason for a good deal of the grambling among the commercial community is owing to the unfinished state of the port and the great difficulties which the officials have had to contend with in the organisation of a town on a site which but a short time ago was utterly unihabited. The energy that has been displayed in the creation of Port Sudan reflects the greatest credit on the ANglo-Sudanese officials, to whom this arduous and important task was entrusted. Of course it is not to be expected that the official and commercial sections of the little community can look at matters from the same point of view and the critacism and grumbling that ensue act as healthy corectives to bureaucractic optimism, but the difficulties which engender this discontent are in a great measure inevitable in such an enterprise, and will no doubt in course of time disappear as experiance is gained.

div.head: The Sudan's Future
div.p: In an interwiew recently published by several Europess papers. M stini, ex member of the Italian Chaebor of Deputies, gave expression to views and opinions on the future of the Sudan which haye not received sufficient attention from the local Prees. According to the ex-legislator the Sudan is to be the Land of Promise for the future. It will one day be the home of millions working on its fertile grounds or in its numerous manufacturies. It will fill the towns and markets of Europe with its goods and natural products. The poorer classes of Italy were advised to migrate to the Sudan instead of going to America and to begin the work of civilisation in it now or others will take the first place before them in this land of the future

Of all people on earth, we are most interest ed in the Sudan and its future, as that country is being nursed and nourished by our own capital. We are spending millions upon the Sudan in the hope of seeing it live one day upon its own means and pay back its debts with or without interest. If M. Ostini is right in his prediction Egypt ought to be well represented and pre emivently interested in the future of that southern part of the Nile Valley But it appears to us that such a future is still very far and that upless the millions of emigrants from Italy and other parts of Europe flood the Sudan during our lease of life we are pot destined to see the blessing of that golden age. As far as we can see wow there is absolutely no hope of filling the Sudan with European emigrants and colonists. We are of opinion that that country is not even thought of by Italians who have their own possession in East Afriea in many ways better for purposes of coloniastion-than the Egyptian Sudan

Our readers will remember, perhaps, a former article in these colamus on the same subject. In that article. we thought that the Arab tribes now living almost on theft and plunder might be induced and even helped by public funds to chauge their present haunts and live im some part of the Sudan. These bedouins are a public danger im Eyypt.as one may prove by the-etheialetatietios of crime, it transfered to the Budan and given lands to cultivate and live upon they will find it no more accessary to rob and steal; they will settle down like all other peaceful subjects and help in improving the condition of their new home. It must be remembered that these Arabs are better fitted for life in the Sudan than European for physical and moral reasons not far to seek.

div.head: Christian Egypt
div.p: To ordinary readers who are religious mystics or students of folklore, perhaps therefore interested in endeavouring to trace the origin of, or connection between the fabulous exploits and puerile miracles attributed to the Egyptian Christian Ascetics and those known from other myths and wonder tales of paganism, the chief value of Dr. Budge''s book on Palladins' history of the monks and ascetics of Christian Egypt will be the preface. In this he gives some excellent remarks concerning the rise and the practices of Egyptian Monasticism Althongh some of the marvellous alleged performances of the monks and men, and many of their references to the underworld, and the future life, and the visits in the world from spirits and demons betray a close and certain conneetion with the old theology and magic of the ancient Egyptian cults and myths there is no reason to think that the practice of Monasticism itself was inherited or imitated from any recluse like life lived by devotees of the old Egyptian deities.

It is true that the sacred hierarchies of the ancient temples and shrines were numerous and devoted for life in many cases to the worship of the god in whose temple they from an early age had been hierophants. But they do not appear to bave in any sense lived an ascetic life, and certainly did not abstain from marriage because many of the chief priestly, and even minor temple, offices such as the canophores and flabellifers were hereditary. Further, in the old religious books no trace of the glorifi cation of abstinence is to be found, but rather the greatest beatitude appears to have been the anticipatory Elysian feasts of innumerable comestibles and beverages.

It would therefore rather seem monasticism of Christian Egypt from the flight from prosecution of numbers of Christians who, in the third century, and some perhaps previously, in order to escape death or torture took refuge in the desert, and remained concealed there during the lengthy Roman imperial persecutions. There enforced poverty and hunger many of the refugees whose nature and inclined them to asceticism ascertained by practice that plain living and quiet contemplation addne with God and the desert world aspect of nature produced in their case a contentment spiritual ecstacy not to be achieved in the turmoil and temptation of the ordinary world and caused them to continue living a recluse's existence, when the necessity for it as far as martyrdom was concerned had passed away, and to endeav our to induce others to follow their example.

Theausterities at first forced upon their when no longer a necessity became practices of self abnegation, and their loneliness of life and the stern face of nature familiar to them in the Libyan or Red Sea wilderness, may be some excuse for their dreams and the imaginary exploits they or their admirers for them have written that they enjoyed or passed through. When the monkish life fashionable the laity out of pity furnished the reclase with food and stimulated them by laudatory encouragements; false sheep then entered the fold and idolent and neurotic ascetics of both sexes probably abounded. The mystic experiences of the genuine early monks were travestied by fabulous stories of the inferior later followers who strove by their exaggerations and falsehoods to enbance their reputation for a piety they perhaps failed to possess.

If no monkish ancestry or prototypes can be detected in the old Egyptian religious books or temple and tomb inscriptions, still less can the great saving truths of Christianity be traced back to the old theology. As Dr Badge well brings out, the old religion was a sort of magic, all hope of reaching heaven being based upon the performance of ceremonies, and the recital of formulae, and whilst the texts written and perused by the pious ancient Egyptians make great boasts of moral perfections such as dutifulness to parents and kindness to relatives and the poor, also integrity where is any meution made of regret or sorrow for sin or offences, and this although the idea of retribution in the next world was commonly held.

It would look as if they ragarded a breach of the moral laws as being remidiably by subsequent good works or the payment of offerings, a sort of system of indulgences as raised the ire of Luther. There was not any ancient Egyptian word for repentance therefore for the Coptic new testament a fresh word "netania," was borrowed from the Greek. Indeed the three fundamental ideas of the Christian religion-repentance, conscience and faith appear to have been unknown, or if known, ignored by the pagan priesthood This being so it might be anticipated that the early Egyptian monks would not very purely apprehend the doctrines of the Christian faith and we find this to be the case, for many of them, apparently, based their salvation upon their own works in the form of fasts, excessive labour and ceaseless strife against freshly appetities.

div.head: Deir El Bahart
div.p: The Record of a Great Work

The first part of the Memoir on the XIth, Dynasty Temple at Deir el,Baliari bas now been published by the Egyptian Exploration Fund, and is a noteworthy volome. It-contains the record of a great achievement, and will be of absorbing interest to all those who, are interested in the subject of Egyptian research. A great deal hasalready appeared-in regarding the Temple and its excavation, but in the present work Dr. Naville and-Messta H R. Hall and E.R Ayrton are able to, give a more concise account of their labours although as Dr. Naville explains in the preface, this Memoir must still be considered as'the description of a work which was unfinished at the time it was prepared. The final plan, which could only be made when the whele building had been cleared, and-therefore~could not appear in this volume, will probably give further important indications as to the date of certain parts of the construction. The second portion of the Memoir is expected to be ready during the next few months.

The task of excavating the site at Deir el- Bahari, commenced fourteen years ago, was completed last season, after the expenditure of an infinite amount of labour and money. The work proved mach more arduous and ex pensive than was at first anticipated, but it can be claimed at the same time that the results of this research have exceeded in value and beauty the highest expectations. The Egypt Expleration Fund are to be congratalat ed upon their determination to go through with the task not withstanding the scarcity of funds, and they have the satisfaction of knowing that they have opened up one of the most interesting sites in this wonderful country, and have thus greatly assisted the cause of Egyp- tian learning. As Professor Naville stated in his paper read at the meeting of the Fund the other day, the money has not been spent in vain, and the final result is worthy of the labour and expense it has cost. To Dr. Navilléhimagli belongs much of the credit for the sucecessful issue of the excavations. He has devoted much time and patience to them, and his services will be all the more appreciated when it is re membered that he has laboured without fee ot reward, and even paid his own travelling ex penses. This devotion finds a worthy place in the record of Egyptological research.

Dr. Naville bas had the assistance of a number of able lieutenants Mr. Hall, Mr: Ayrton, Mr. O. T. Currelly, Mr. Garnett—Orme, Mr: M. D. Dalison, Mr. J. 'T. Dennis, and inst, but by no means least, Madam Naville, wha has prepared many artistic plates for the Memoirs.

The plates contained in the present Memoir are the great feature of the work, and are without exception very beautiful. Probably the best is that ot the Hator-Cow made from a water colour by Mr. C. M. Reach. The plan of the Temple at the end of the third season, 1906, drawn by Mr. C. R. Peers, from working plans by Messrs. Ayrton aod Currelly, gives a very good idea of the Temple as then excavated.

Although before Anthony obtained such celebrity as a recluse a certain Paul was a noted ascetic, there cannot be any doubt it was to the devout life of the former that Egyptian monasticism owed its vogue and rapid growth. The monastery which be finally foanded was situated about 25 miles from the Red Sea, and not later not far away from it another anchorite of the name of Paul established a large monastic settlement. Barly in the tourta century Pacho. mius drew up the celebratéd "Rule" for his followers, the practice of which code is display- éd so tully in the Asketikon or History of the monks of 'Tabena which form an impertant portion of Palladias Work.

He however wandered about Egypt visiting all the chief novastic communities such as those in the Nitrian desert North West of Cairo, where he says there were 5,000 monks and 600 anchorites. He also speaks highly of the monks and hermite of Antinoe where he resided four years.The chapters of Dr. Budges introduction are devoted to a disoussion of the superpatural and mythical demauds in these Histories of Palladuis and to the ascetic life and teaching of its votaries. Though Palladuis appears to an admirer of the monkish career he in his history illustrates both its strength and weakness and although many impossible miracles and actions are recited, yet, as Dr. Budge says:-

"The great merit of Palladnis "Paradise" is that the histories make the reader feel, when reading them, that he has not before him naratives of the lines of a set of beings of supernatural character but stories of men who were trying to live super-human lives and a Palfaduis shows clearly how far they succeeded and in what they failed. He was no more panegyrist of the monks but a patient sober and impartial critic of their lines words and deeds. In several of his biographies of them he admits that they relapsed into worldieness and sin.

The abstemious life of a recluse the clear desert air of Egypt might, in many instances be supposed to have been congenial to an excessive longevity, but the greatest span of life attributed to a monk is 133 years for a certain Mar Paul; another Elijah of Antinoe lived a 100 years; and Anthony 105. These are not longer than the age accomplished by the writer of the old Egyptian papyri : or than terms which have been equalled, if not exceeed, in modern times especially in Russia. There are very few historical gleanings to be obtained from the work. Two governors are mentioned Alipius and Lausaus which may be Perfecti Aegyptii, and the papyrus plant is stated to have neen still growing in lake Moreotis in the fourth century. The quotation from Scripture are evidently carelessly made and so not of much value for textual criticism.

div.head: Army and Navy
div.p: The Grenadier Guard's inquiry case closed yesterday, no doubt to the relief of all con cerned. One cannot help but ask "where the good of holding the inquiry at all" Certaivly it did not make good reading, it served no good object, and it gave the yellow press an opportunity of displaying scare headlones and indulging in the usual bosh on the service maters. One thing would require explanation, and that is, if Lieutenant Woods was unfit to be a regimental officer why was he recommended for service in the Egyptian Army last year, or why was he told to go to Uganda. If he was unfit to serve in London he was unfit to serve in either country.

An echo of the famous ''on the knee" case is to be found in a new Admiralty order, just published, to the effect that as far as possible seamen and stokers at Portsmouth are to live a float instead of at shore establishments. This goes well to substantiate what was stated dur ing the stokers' riots of just a year ago that the naval barracks, where the riots occurred, would be vacated by the bluejackets and taken over by the Royal "Marine Light' Infantry, When the "stone frigates" were built, the policy of housing the bluejackets in them was severely criticised on the grounds that it would not make for' the maintenance of good order and discipline, and that certainly it woald not im- prove the standard of seamanship. The un- fortunate sequel proved the truth of the criticisms.

The 9.2 guns for the armoured cruiser "Minotaur" are said to be the finest weapons ever manufactured in that particular calibre. This gun weighs 29 tons, has a length of 39 feet, and is worked electrically. Its projectile weighs the regulation 380 lbs, and the powder charge consists of 130 lbs cordite, the explosion of which propels the projectile at a velocity of 2,900 feet per second, or with an initial energy lof 21,000 foottons. The extreme range of the gun is 12,000 yards—nearly seven miles—and at the liberal fightings range of 3,000 yards the projectile cam punch 11 inches of steel ar: mour. The "Minotaur" carries, or rather will carry, as they have not yet been mounted, four of these guns.

Inniskilling Dragoons of all ranks look for ward with regret to the time when Colonel E. A. Herbert, M.V.O., will sever his connection with the grand old regiment at Cairo. No more popalar officer has ever ridden at its head in modern yéars. He has spent nearly all his twenty one years' service with it, and comman- ded the C. Squadron in the early stages of the Boer War. At theaction of Barnard's Nek he did a veryplucky thing in-chrrging, with only thirteen men behind him, a force of 200 Boers, cutting his way through them. His horse was shot and a trumpeter brought him in on his horse. This charge was necessary to gain an important kopje, which he subsequently held against all the force that the Boers could bring against his handful of men, five of whom, were killed and five wounded. Unfortunately, he had to be invalided home through sickness in Febraary, 1900, and did not rejoin till the December of the following year when he went out from England in Command of a draft for the regiment, which was the operating along the Heilbron Frankfort line, and served with it till the close of the struggle

In his remarks on the training carried out by the troops in the Aldershot Gommand this year, Getioral Sir John Fretich emphasises the Importance, as regards 'tactics, of paying in- creased attention to the study of the topography of any probable field of battle. In view of the enormous comparative extent of modern battlefields, that of Mukden, for example, as Compared with the fields of Water loo and Ligny, this study of ground. is much more important than was formerly 'the case, the ngnwrous and varied featares of ground having necessarily exercised a vastly greater influéence'in the great 'battles of 1905 than was exercised by topegraphical conditions in those of 1615. In connection with the training of the Cavalry, an excellent piece of work is recorded of the 1st Cavalry Brigade, the whole brigade having carried oot thé swimming of the Thames by night in so short a time as to constitute it an almost unique performance. The main feature in connection with the training of the Royal Engineers was the marked improvement made as regards wireless telegraphy, the stations being rapidly put up, and Communication being continnously maintained. In the Infantry the system of training by double com pemics Was oootineed, with results that prove, in the opinion of SIr John French, that the longer the system of double company organisation is tried, the more apparent does its value become. An extended develepment is recommended by the system of detailing medical officers to take part in staff tours, which affords an excellent method of teaching the various medical and sanitary problems to be met within war, and of discovering the capabilities of officers.

div.head: New Guide to Palestine
div.p: The "New Guide to the Holy Land", which has been compiled by Father Barnabas Meis- termann, under the direction of the Castodian of the Holy Land, and has been translated from the French mto the English, Italian, German, and Spanish langoages, will be found a very useful volume not merély by Catholic pilgrims and tourists, for whom it is ostensibly written, but 'also by the incréasing numbers of the travelling public who visit Palestine from time to time. Father Meistermann has lived many years in the Holy Land, and has exploted it trom enc tovend. He has thas been enabled to give, in a compact form, a great amount of information regarding the features of interest to be noted, and many hints as to the best means of making a tour in comfort. The work is divided into twenty-six excursions, and as there are twenty-two excellent maps and over one-hundred plans, each day's journey can be arranged and carried out without many of the little inconvenieces which of fires render travelling in the Bast somewhat weéarisonre The guide contains a well-condensed bistory of the Holy Land, and a éhapter on the political divisions of the country, Some very helpful advice as to outfit and hygienic precautions is also given.

These plans include Marseiles, Naples, the Piraeus and Athens, Contantinople, Alexandria, and the Tower of the Forty Martyrs at Ramleh. A preface to the English edition is contributed by the Bishop of salford. The guide is published by Messrs Burn and Oates, Ltd., Orchard St. W., price 7/6

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: On a ouvert avec de l'animation, mais l chiffre d'affaires est resté minime; au surplu en cours de séance le ton a perdu de sa fer meté et la clôture a eu lieu au calme plat. A s'en rapporter à la cote on croirait que le mar ché a été remarquable à tous les points de vue beaucoup de titres sont en hausse, dont quel ques-uns de façon marquée. Cependant, comme nous venons de le dire, il s'agit en général de cours nominaux, inscrits en fin de séance au milieu d'un tapage assourdissant. Le fait est que si les vendeurs sont réservés, les acheteurs le sont aussi; chacun reste chez soi. En valeurs dirigeantes la tenue a été inégale, l'Agricole et la Delta Light étant fermes, tandis que la Na- tional Bank était offerte. En tous cas, ce n'est pas l'appui de Londres qui nous a manqué, puisque le taux privé d'escompte nous est arri- vée en réduction sensible et que nos valeurs sont soutenues au Stock Exchange. On allègue pour expliquer la lourdeur que certains ont hâte de réaliser et sont constamment à l'affût des occasions.

L'Agricole progresse de 7 7/8 à 7 29/32, la Delta Light de 9 3/4 à 9 25/32, la Daïra de 12 11/16 à 12 13/16, et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 286 1/2 à 287 l'ancienne et de 253 à 253 1/2 la nouvelle. Quant à la National Bank elle revient de 20 5 8 à 20 1/2.
Tandis que les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alex- andrie reculent de 140 à 138, les Dividendes avancent de 272 à 278. L'Alexandria Water gagne une demi-livre à 10 3/4 et les Eaux do Caire 3 franes à 103.

En hausse encore les Lots Turcs de 158 à 159, la Banque d'Athènes de 112 3/4 à 113 1 4, la Privilégiée Khedivial Mail de 4 à 4 1/4, la Land Bank de 7 3/16 à 7 9/32, l'Urbaine de 3 1/4 à 3 3/8, l'Union Foncière de 4 3,8 à 4 7/16, et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1,8 à 47/32. La Banque d'Orient rétrograde de 115 à 114.

Dans la catégorie des petites valeurs, la Cassa di Sconto avance de 42 1/2 à 43, la Building Lands de 1 19/32 à 1 5/8, l'Aboukir de 26/3 à 27/6, l'action Allotment de 1 7/8 à 2, la Port Said Salt de 12/3 à 12/4 1/2, les Ritz de 5/16 à 11/32 et la Levico de 11/32 à 3/8. La Delta Land fléchit, au contraire, de 19/32 à 1 1/4 et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 23/6 22/9.

Pour cette dernière le bilan publié est fa vorable. Après que les actions privilégiées auront touché leur 5 1/2% statutaire et les or dinary 10%, il restera un report à nouveau de £14000, suffisant pour le dividende de l'année prochaine.
L'ouverture de la séance a été retardée d'un quart d'heure en signe de deuil pour la mort de M. Reid, l'un des chefs de la maison Reid & Barnard de Londres.

div.head: GOMME ARABIQUE
div.p: Il n'y a pas de stock à Londres. A Alexan- drie il n'y a en a que très peu, chez un seul négociant. A Suez il n'y a que 2000 colis en tout.
On attend les premiers arrivages à Duem au commencement de Décembre. D'ici là, les prix. se maintiendront très élevés en Angleterre et sur le Continent.

Il est à croire que la prochaine récolte de gomme sera très belle, car celle du maïs ayant été plutôt mauvaise, par suite du grand exces de pluies, l'indigène, pris par le besoin, se donnera la peine cette fois-ci d'aller recueillir la gomme.

On parle beaucoup du projet qu'aurait le Gouvernement du Soudan de créer des routes, un chemin de fer même, qui iraient jusqu'au cœur du Kordofan. Il y a dans ce pays des forêts immenses produisant de la gomme, mais qui n'ont pu jusqu'ici être exploitées par suite du manque de la main-d'oeuvre et des moyens de transport, très peu sûrs et très lents en tous cas.

Si le projet du Gouvernement du Soudan est mis à exécution, le commerce des gommes prendra une importance dont il est impossible, à l'heure actuelle, de calculer la grandeur. Exportation des gommes arabiques pendant le mois de Septembre 1907. Total: 292.819 kilos valant ... Contre 624.888
Du ler Janvier à fin Septembre 1907 l'ex-
Kilos 3.103.815 valant L E. 57.966 contre 5 614.128 valant,, 115.711 en 1906
N.B.-Nous avons reçu une lettre d'un de

nos lecteurs nous disant qu'une erreur avait T da se glisser dans l'établissement de nos chif- fres, en ce qui est de l'exportation des gommes, de beaucoup supérieure à celle que nous indi- quons. Nous faisons remarquer que nos statis- tiques sont rigoureusement établies sur les A données officielles du Gouvernement Egyptien C et qu'elles sont absolument exactes. Il est bien entendu que ces statistiques ne concernent que le Commerce de l'Egypte exclusivement, et qu'elles ne comprennent pas les transactions commerciales du Soudan se faisant directement par voie de Port-Soudan, situé sur le territoire appartenant au Gouvernement du Soudan.

div.head: The Cairo Sewage Transport Company Limited.
div.p: The Annual General Meeting of the share- holders of the above mentioned Company will be held on Saturday the 21st day of December, 1907, at 4 p.m., in the Cairo Office of the Company, No 1, Sharia El Cherifein.
The business to be transacted comprises the following:-

1.-Reading the report of the Directors including the accounts for the twelve months ended 30th September, 1907, approving the same and declaring a divi- dend. 2.-Reading the report of the Auditor. 3.-Electing an Auditor for the year 1908 and fixing his remuneration.
4.-Electing a Director in accordance with Articles Nos. 37 and 38 of the Articles of Association.

In accordance with the provisions of Art. 21 of the said Articles such shareholders as wish to be present at this meeting, either in person or by proxy, should deposit their shares with the Bankers of the Company in Cairo three days previous to the meeting, and the receipts alone, which they shall obtain in exchange, shall give the right to attend the meeting
Shares will be received at the Bank of Egypt, Limited, from 9 o'clock to 11 up to the 18th December, 1907.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de PEtat Egyption.
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au Mercredi, buit Janvier 1908, à midi au plus tard, des offres pour l'achat des vieux maté riaax déposés dans ses Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) où ils peuvent être examinés cha que jour de neuf heures du matin à une heure pm., les Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés, et ce conformément aux conditions du Cahier des Charges relatif à ces matériaux et suivant la liste y annexée dont un exemplaire peut être obtenu au Bureau de M. l'Inspecteur des Maga sins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) et à celui du Chef du Service des Magasins Généraux à Boulac (Caire), contre paiement de 100 (cent Millièmes).

Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette adjudication doit, au préalable, déposer à la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire, à titre de cautionnement provisoire, une somme égale à 5 (Cinq pour cent) de la valeur totale des matériaux, calculée d'après les prix sou- missionnés, ou se conformer aux prescriptions de l'article 9 du Cahier des Charges.
Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente millièmes. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli re- commandé à :-
et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante :
"Offre pour Achat de Vieux Matériaux." Toute offre faite ou déposée postérieurement au jour et à l'heure ci dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.

L'Administration se réserve le droit de choisir parmi les offres, celles qui lui convien- nent, sans être tenue d'accepter l'offre la plus élevée ni n'importe quelle offre. Elle se ré- serve de même le droit de distribuer et diviser les lots et de ne donner aucune suite aux son- missions présentées, quels que soient les prix offerts.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life.
